data.text: How Do You Keep Your Shoes Dry when Bikepacking in the Rain

Hello, So what do you guys do to keep your shoes/feet dry. I'm considering buying the five ten trail cross pro mtb shoes(with goretex). But I really like the five ten freerider shoes. They're insanely comfortable to me and much cheaper. I've been reading about waterproof socks, overshoes, using plastic bags. What are your opinions/solutions for this issue? Thanks

We experimented with all sorts of stuff and in the end settled on waterproof socks. We use light, breathable, quick-drying shoes and just let them get wet and subsequently dry again, but use the socks to keep our feet dry. The socks are super warm and cosy too. üëç
data.author: Dave Henderson

data.text: thanks for the info. I'm thinking about going that route too.
data.author: Miltiades Konstantaras

data.text: Not sure there‚Äôs a 100% solution to this that‚Äôs reasonable so merino wool socks for me

data.author: Dean Poshard

data.text: I just use Merino wool socks. Even when your feet are wet they are still warm. Ôøº
data.author: Robert Loftin

data.text: I have waterproof non-insulated shoe covers that fasten with Velcro at the back. They are easy to put on and take off. My shoes take a long time to dry if they get soaked.
data.author: Jacquie Gaudet

data.author: Jacquie Gaudet

data.text: Goretex shoes 1st choice, 2nd choice Showers Pass waterproof socks When regular shoes soak up water, won't matter if your merino socks keep you warm, those shoes will take many many hours to dry still. Why not regular waterproof hiking shoes with mountain biking pedals with better pins or wider pedal surface?
data.author: Jeff Blackmore

data.text: I use Five Ten shoes without GoreTex and Sealskinz socks. Additionally i have some Endura overshoes for flat pedals. My problem with GoreTex shoes was, if these shoes are wet it takes a long time to get them dry.
data.author: Silvio Schl√∂ffel

data.text: Goretex shoes and ankle gaiters to keep water out.
data.author: Steve Coombs

data.text: Goretex shoes... Once it gets soaked (and it will in heavy rain) , it will take a few days to dry.
data.author: Paulo Pereira

data.text: Coming from the backpacking community, there‚Äôs no such thing as waterproof shoes because they all have this giant hole at the top where your foot goes in. What ‚Äúwaterproof‚Äù shoes are in actuality are buckets. What‚Äôs necessary to do first is change your mindset and accept that if you‚Äôre in wet conditions, your feet are going to get wet. What your focus should be on is how to get them dry quickly once the rain stops. This is accomplished in two ways: first, by having 2 backup pairs of socks, and second, by having non waterproof shoes. Non waterproof shoes will dry out relatively quickly. If you‚Äôre at the end of the day, great, let them air out, hang up your socks to dry, and let your feet dry inside the tent. If the rain stops in the middle of the day though, you‚Äôve got a different issue. Here‚Äôs where the two pairs of socks come in. The rain stops, you take your shoes and socks off and let your feet dry. Put on your first backup pair of socks on, put your shoes back on, keep peddling. Your shoes will dry out quickly because the interior is wicking into your dry socks, and the exterior is drying in contact with the air. Eventually, you‚Äôll wind up with dry shoes and damp socks. Switch out the damp ones for your second backup pair and voila, good to go. Hang up both pairs of wet socks off your kit while you ride and you‚Äôre back to where you started.
data.author: Justin Ammerman

data.text: love this answer. Thank you.
data.author: Miltiades Konstantaras

data.text: now that just makes a whole lot of sense-probably the best tip I‚Äôve read in ages! Thank you üëå
data.author: Kevin Still

data.text: happy to help. Saw lots of recommendations for waterproof socks in here that left me scratching my head going ü§î all waterproof socks do is trap your gnarly foot sweat in the sock with you so it can‚Äôt evaporate. Always better off with fresh, dry, preferably merino socks to change into.
data.author: Justin Ammerman

data.text: Yes never liked the waterproof sock approach either! Often the simplest things are the best-instead of carrying one pair of socks, carry two-how have I not thought of that!!!!! üôà
data.author: Kevin Still

data.text: old military adage I picked up when I was in the service: ‚ÄúTwo is one, one is none.‚Äù
data.author: Justin Ammerman

data.text: great advice, I do the same thing but use Chaco or bedrock sandals instead. Dry faster and can use without socks if weather permits.
data.author: Tim Carlson

data.text:
if you like the sandal route take a look at these. By far my favorite on and off trail. Weigh almost nothing, super sturdy, take up virtually no space in your pack. https://xeroshoes.com/shop/sandals/ztrail-men/
Z-Trail EV - Men - Xero Shoes
xeroshoes.com
data.author: Justin Ammerman

data.text: Justin's comments about not wearing waterproof shoes are right. They will not dry and every morning you will put on not only wet shoes, but many times frozen shoes.
data.author: Tom Kendall

data.text: yep. The only thing worse than wet shoes are frozen shoes.
data.author: Justin Ammerman

data.text: We bought waterproof socks but haven‚Äôt used them yet.
data.author: Bret Alexander Schnitzer

data.text: I have tried waterproof socks. Many riders use them. From my experience, they will keep your feet dry but eventually will get wet. Once wet, they are heavy and a beast to dry out. I simply wear wool socks and liners under my socks.
data.author: Tom Kendall

data.text: thanks. Merino wool?
data.author: Bret Alexander Schnitzer

data.text: Darn tough socks and I use Injinji liner toe socks. Tough to get on but once the toe socks are it's heaven.
data.author: Tom Kendall

data.text: After years of using seal skins with freerider pros, and other five tens before them, I bought the trail cross GTX this winter. I‚Äôm in NW England so we know about wet feet. I wish these shoes were available 20 years ago. What a revelation. Finally warm dry feet! The thing with sealskins is that once your shoe & the outer acrylic sock are saturated, either water will find its way through or their breathability is shot because vapour can‚Äôt get out through all the saturated cloth & you still get wet and cold feet. When they do get totally wet, I put my foot in a river and it went over the top, they dry out faster than my freerider pros. You do need to wear them with trousers with an ankle cuff that covers the top of the boot though, or it‚Äôs pointless. Rain will run down the top. They grip as well as the freerider pros & seem to have a stiffer sole than the none gtx trail cross models (like the FR Pro). Value wise I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs that bad. They make a good light duty hiking shoe and seal skins never last more than a season before there‚Äôs a hole in the membrane anyway. I‚Äôd hope to get a few years out of these.
data.author: Tim Williams

data.text: In winter I ride in walking/mountain boots. The raine still runs in the top from my waterproof trousers. I have invested in some gators. But haven‚Äôt had chance to put them to the test yet.
data.author: Julian Clarke

data.text: Goretex socks are the bomb. There when you need it. Not when you don't. I can't wear gt shoes all the time. They are too hot.
data.author: Derek Heffernan

data.text: Keen sandals, wool socks. Summer time rider only.
data.author: Lee Hollenbeck

data.text: Your Comfort is what matters most. Trust your own experience. I used Alltra‚Äôs WITH inserts. Worked great.
data.author: Michael R Travis

data.text: I have pearl Izumi shoe booties, expensive, bulky but effective and more designed for cold temps. Waxing is a viable option, waterproof spray and, when bikepacking where you are constantly in a state of space and weight management, I have used plastic bags from the grocery store. Slide your foot in, tie it on the ankle and you‚Äôre set. I have also tried waterproof socks from Sealskinz. They worked great but your sweat will never leave your foot.
data.author: Jeff Glessing

data.text: And let's hope that we won't exceed 1.5 degrees of warming......
data.author: Ronald van Walraven

data.text: I've got both 5.10 Freerider and the Cross. Very similar sole, but love the uppers of the Cross well above the Freerider. The Cross are much more comfirtable for hike-a-bike, much more ventilated (odd for goretex) and feel less heavy (even tho weights are similar in my scales). The Freeriders' uppers are way too hot and their excess padding retains water forever.
data.author: Brad Coombes

data.text: do you have the five ten freerider canvas or pro? The only thing I'm concerned about is that I have wide ass feet and the cross is kind of narrow. I was thinking about starting with the five ten canvas and maybe buying the cross later
data.author: Miltiades Konstantaras

data.text: I've don't have the canvas version. I have wide feet at the widest point (so for hiking I wear altra lone peak etc). I find the Cross more accommodating. It is apparently narrower but the extra padding/material in the Freerider cancels that out
data.author: Brad Coombes

data.text: I‚Äôve been commuting in Chicago for 2 years(winters too) now and have a few tricks for wet weather. My favorite combo for non freezing wet riding is Chaco sandals and wool socks. I bring a few pairs too in a dry bag. Wool is special because it holds it warmth even when wet. Once you get to your destination change out the wet socks for dry ones and put the sandals back on. It gets cold, put on extra socks or I‚Äôve I‚Äôve even used grocery bags over the socks when it‚Äôs freezing rain. Riding in the rain is inevitable but the main trick is get dry as fast and stay warm.
data.author: Tim Carlson

data.text: I use waterproof uninsulated shoe covers that fasten in the back with Velcro (easy to get on and off). They have a hold for cleats but that part of any shoe should be waterproof.
data.author: Jacquie Gaudet
